author: Jerit Roser, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: 'LSU has shown the power of sports and unity,' South Carolina native writes
text:
LSU's efforts to welcome South Carolina to Baton Rouge this weekend and make the Gamecocks feel more like the "home" team they'll technically be Saturday in Tiger Stadium, some of which probably won't be evident until after kickoff, have garnered praise the past few days.
The university's band, for instance, will play their visiting hosts' fight song and alma mater , for instance, while billboards around the city welcome the SEC rivals to town, where officials have given their guests the keys to the stadium.
All proceeds raised from the game, minus the expenses necessary to fund the event, will go to South Carolina to help in the recovery process from recent storms and floods that devastated much of the area.
The still-growing list of displays of hospitality have shown the rest of the college football community the power of sports and unity, South Carolina native Mattis Collier wrote for the website The Odyssey , "a social content platform that crowdsources ideas from millennial thought leaders in their local communities."
"LSU has shown how sports aren't just about winning and losing," Collier wrote. "LSU has shown the sportsmanship and unity we like to see emerge from sports. While these storms have shown a cruel and unrelenting side of Mother Nature, they have also given us the opportunity to witness compassion.
"Louisiana understands the power of a natural disaster and the response needed from those in surrounding areas from their experiences with Hurricane Katrina, and this is proven with how they have handled this game."
